content: This question used to be in clash of code but was removed because it was too difficult to do in 5 minutes...

Although this problem would make an easy community puzzle, I see two main reasons to switch to this mode:

1. The only reliable way to solve this puzzle in limited time is to fetch the formulas on some random website. I can rediscover these formulas and code them within 5 minutes, but I doubt this will make it in Fastest mode.

2. A solution for this problem may come in handy in order to code a bot for some multiplayer games. So it would be nice to have time to polish the solution and the ability to save it (without having to rely on some external tool).


Moreover, I think that Reverse mode is almost impossible if one has never seen the problem before. Shortest mode is the only relevant mode if this problem is to become a CoC.

It's a mathematical problem, not a computer programing one.

You should give the mathematical method in the goal description (or simply a hint ?)
this ons is good for me . i think blind mode does not feet. Might be too complicated if it's the first time you see the problem.

The second case of your first test seems false.
Nope, everything is OK.

Please do not use language-specific terms "true" and "false". Instead you could use "inside" and "outside". This is critical for some languages like Python where the built-in terms are different ("True" and "False"), which makes the solution unnecessarily longer compared to other languages.

Many computer programming problems come down to mathematical ones. I don't see what's the big deal here, it's quite simple actually. And no, I'm not a "mathgeek" or anything similar, if anything I pretty much hate math :)

It's quite simple, but not simple enough to be done without some research by most people.
It could be a community puzzle instead of clash of code...
It can make people prefer one language over another, but then again, why is that a bad thing?
If people always use "true/false", it will always favor the same languages. So I am happy with the choice of "inside/outside" here.
